Based on my search, here's what I found regarding Tolkien scholarship, academic research, mythology, linguistics, philology, university courses, and scholarly journals in 2024:

## Scholarly Journals

The field is served by several key scholarly publications:

**Tolkien Studies: An Annual Scholarly Review** is the premier academic journal founded in 2004 publishing papers on the works of J.R.R. Tolkien. Volume 21 was published in 2024, and the journal presents the growing body of critical commentary and scholarship on both J.R.R. Tolkien's voluminous fiction and his academic work in literary and linguistic fields.

**Journal of Tolkien Research (JTR)** is a peer-reviewed electronic journal with the goal of providing high-quality research and scholarship based on the works of J.R.R. Tolkien and on transformative and derivative texts based on his work to a wide and diverse audience. Recent 2024 research includes work on "A Time of Fire and Cataclysm": The Centrality of Cosmic War in Tolkien's Round World Cosmologies and explorations of linguistic elements in Middle-earth.

## Academic Research Areas

Current Tolkien scholarship encompasses diverse disciplines. Scholars from different disciplines have examined the linguistic and literary origins of Middle-earth, and have explored many aspects of his writings from Christianity to feminism and race. Research focuses include:

- **Philological Studies**: Some scholars have investigated its philological roots in languages such as Old Norse and Old English
- **Linguistic Research**: Tolkien's constructed languages, Quenya and Sindarin, the main languages of Elves, have inspired linguistic research
- **Literary Analysis**: New books, monographs, and papers continue to be published to this day on Tolkien's writings in core areas such as literary analysis, philology, and constructed languages, with applications to topics as diverse as politics, economics, and gender studies

## University Courses

Several universities offer Tolkien-focused coursework:

Rice University offers a course on The Lord of the Rings and The Hobbit as a mythology for England. Rutgers University offers a course on Christian elements found in The Lord of the Rings. Victoria University of Wellington offers a course on The Lord of the Rings and how it relates to medieval literature. Bethel University offers a course on the theology of Middle-earth.

**Signum University** offers specialized degree concentrations, including study of Tolkien's wealth of stories, poems, essays, lectures, letters, and notes that scholars have continued to study for decades after his death.

## Current State of the Field

Tolkien scholarship has begun to expand into new and bigger areas. This is due partly to the popularity of blockbuster movies made from Tolkien's The Lord of the Rings and The Hobbit. However, it is also due to the growth of online forums where scholars, enthusiasts, and fans can come together to discuss their intuitions, ideas, and insights with respect to Tolkien's works.

The field continues to be productive with a lot of people working in Tolkien studies today, and essays and explorations of Tolkien's work, biography, and impact can appear in almost any academic journal.
